title: 115_hr1957
content: The "Safe Schools Improvement Act of 2017" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Congress finds that bullying and harassment in schools can seriously harm students' physical and psychological health, leading to academic issues such as high dropout rates and absenteeism. These behaviors include physical violence, name-calling, intimidation, social exclusion, and cyberbullying. Students who participate in educational activities at schools may experience bullying and harassment through various means such as physical violence, name-calling, social exclusion, and cyberbullying. Schools with anti-bullying policies see increased reporting and teacher intervention, leading to a reduction in such incidents. Bullying and harassment often target students based on factors like race, gender, disability, and sexual orientation. Interventions to address bullying and harassment in schools aim to create a positive and safe school climate, utilizing evidence-based discipline policies and practices like Positive Behavior Interventions and Supports (PBIS). Students, particularly those targeted based on race, gender, disability, or sexual orientation, may experience relational aggression or psychological bullying, damaging their relationships with peers and feelings of social acceptance. Interventions to address bullying and harassment in schools, including creating a positive and safe school climate with evidence-based discipline policies like PBIS, can reduce exclusionary discipline practices. 85% of Americans support a Federal law to prevent bullying, showing a call for leadership to address this national crisis. The Safe Schools Improvement Act aims to address bullying and harassment in public elementary and secondary schools by implementing anti-bullying policies. The Safe Schools Improvement Act requires states receiving grants to ensure that all local educational agencies establish policies to prevent severe, persistent, or pervasive bullying and harassment that limits a student's participation or creates a hostile educational environment. The Safe Schools Improvement Act mandates that local educational agencies must have policies to prevent bullying and harassment that create a hostile environment based on various factors like race, gender, disability, or sexual orientation. The Safe Schools Improvement Act requires local educational agencies to have policies prohibiting bullying and harassment based on factors such as race, gender, disability, sexual orientation, and other defining characteristics. These policies must include annual notice to students, parents, and educational professionals about prohibited conduct and grievance procedures for students or parents. The Safe Schools Improvement Act mandates local educational agencies to provide annual notice about prohibited conduct and grievance procedures for complaints regarding bullying and harassment. This includes specifying responsible officials and establishing timelines for complaint resolution. The local educational agency officials responsible for receiving complaints must establish timelines for resolving them. Data on prohibited conduct must be collected annually at the school level and publicly reported, ensuring victims or perpetrators are not identifiable. Positive and preventative approaches to school discipline should be encouraged to minimize student removal. The local educational agency must collect and report data on prohibited conduct at the school level, ensuring confidentiality. Positive and preventative approaches to school discipline should be promoted to reduce student removal from instruction and prevent disproportionate punishment. State reports are required from the chief executive officer of a State receiving a grant under this title, in cooperation with the State educational agency. The report should include information from local educational agencies on prohibited conduct and describe the State's plans to support local educational agency efforts in addressing such conduct. The Secretary conducts biennial evaluations of anti-bullying programs in schools, collects data on prohibited conduct, and submits reports to the President and Congress every two years. The Secretary conducts biennial evaluations of anti-bullying programs in schools and submits reports to the President and Congress every two years on prohibited conduct. "SEC. 4705. EFFECT ON OTHER LAWS." The section clarifies that the obligations outlined do not override existing federal and state nondiscrimination laws, such as the Civil Rights Act of 1964, Education Amendments of 1972, Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. The obligations imposed by this part under the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 are in addition to those imposed by other federal laws such as the Civil Rights Act of 1964, Education Amendments of 1972, and Rehabilitation Act of 1973. Nothing in this part shall affect the rights available to individuals under other federal laws that protect freedom of speech or expression. "Section 4706 states that states and local entities can enact laws to prevent bullying or harassment of students as long as they are not inconsistent with this part of the Safe Schools Improvement Act."
